events.text: UI variables (don't adjust these directly, use the relevant functions)

events.comment: the actual UI component that is focused right now

events.text: this is a lot of code and even with comments it's difficult to put together what everything does, so look for these pink comments for a tl;dr

children.text: when a UI button is created, initialize some properties

actions.text: here, I choose to record the width and height of every button by default so that I can manipulate their sizes for animations later. this isn't required and you could do anything else here, or nothing at all if you wish.
the original size is recorded, for when this button is not chosen and is idle
add the original size to the mouseover size (if you set it to 4 in properties, then it will be 4 more than the original size)

events.title: ui sections
events.description: has events you shouldn't edit, but functions you may call

children.text:
you can think of sections like a collection of buttons. 

on a main menu layout alone you'll probably have multiple sections, such as...

- a 'main' section, which would include buttons with an id like mainPlay, mainSettings, mainQuit, etc.
- a 'mainPlay' section, where upon clicking the mainPlay button, new options appear such as mainPlayNewGame, mainPlayLoadGame, etc.
- a 'mainQuit' section, where clicking mainQuit takes you to mainQuitConfirm and mainQuitCancel
- even more sections like 'mainSettings', which could lead to 'mainSectionsVideo', 'mainSectionGameplay', 'mainSectionControlsKeyboardConfirmBind', who knows!

so long as it's part of the ui family, you should assign a section to it

below are some functions you should use to enable and disable sections. some examples of using these functions are...

- on start of layout, enable section "main"
- on 'mainPlay' selected, disable section "main" and enable section "mainPlay"
- on clicking 'mainPlayNewGame', maybe a transition will happen and fade to a new layout. to make sure no more buttons can be pressed, disable all sections
enable/disable a UI section - this will run a ui update

children.functionDescription: enables a section of UI components - this will run a ui update

children.text: update the UI afterwards

children.functionDescription: disables a section of UI components - this will run a ui update

children.text: update the UI afterwards

children.functionDescription: disables every UI component on the layout - runs a UI update

children.text: update the UI afterwards

events.title: ui behavior
events.description: has custom actions you may edit, but functions you shouldn't call

children.text: some functions here are marked with [INTERNAL], meaning that you shouldn't be using them when making your game unless it's for a specific niche case where you know what you're doing
run a UI update
if button is active
if this button is no longer chosen...

actions.text: call custom action for this button being chosen

children.text: if this button is chosen, and wasn't before...

actions.text: call custom action for this button being chosen, but wait 0 seconds first! this allows the unchoose command to trigger before the choose one

children.text: if not, set button to lower opacity

actions.text: call custom action for this button being chosen, but wait 0 seconds first! this allows the unchoose command to trigger before the choose one

children.text: button custom action handlers

with these custom actions, you can provide a default behavior here, and override the default by creating an override custom action for the button object.

for example, right now it's set so that when you chose a button it grows, and unchoosing it makes it shrink again.

if you want a special button type on some layout to instead become brighter, you can make an override by creating a new custom action for that object, and calling the action "uiChoose" exactly.
you'll know you've done it right because it'll say 'Overridden' next to it.

to learn more about custom actions and overriding, see here --> https://www.construct.net/en/make-games/manuals/construct-3/project-primitives/events/custom-actions

children.functionDescription: use overrides to create special events
use overrides to create special events
use overrides to create special events

actions.text: didn't have any default action I wanted to assign for all buttons on being selected

children.text: selects the currently chosen UI component

will call a function with the syntax ("select " & uiButton.id)
ex: Function "select mainPlay"
add this function to any event sheet to register when a button is selected

keep in mind that if you change a button's ID, you'll have to change the name of its function, too

children.functionDescription: selects the currently chosen UI component

actions.text: call function with js, so that any function name can be called at runtime
call custom action for this button's selection

children.text: the rest of these are internal, so I don't recommend manually calling them anyways

functionParameters.comment: either left, right, up, or down

else, perform the navigation

else, perform normal navigation

next, find the new option to choose depending on the direction
if components exist in this direction, pick the closest of them
if none found, wrap around to UI on the other side of the screen

if none found, wrap around to UI on the other side of the screen

if none found, wrap around to UI on the other side of the screen

events.title: ui interaction
events.description: has events and functions you shouldn't edit

children.text:
this is where the user actually uses inputs to be able to interact with the ui. 
once again I don't recommend messing with any of this stuff...

but, if you want to change how fast it scrolls when you hold a directional button, you could change the constant variables below.
on default, you need to hold down a button for 0.5 seconds, before it starts auto scrolling every 0.1 seconds
how long you need to hold down an input in order to start the auto-scroll behavior
how often the input repeats when auto-scrolling
if ui input was triggered on this frame (make sure this variable is above the events, won't work otherwise)
if gamepad is detected, switch to gamepad controls
mouseover choosing
left click to select option
arrow key navigation
select with enter

children.title: ui interaction gamepad
children.description: keep in mind that only gamepad 0 can navigate the UI

children.text: if kbm is detected, switch to kbm controls
gamepad deadzone for UI navigation
directional navigation using d-pad and left stick
select with enter
arrow key auto scroll timer

children.functionDescription: when player presses a directional input (keyboard or gamepad)

children.text: if the held duration is at 0 (activate immediately on input), otherwise operate on auto timer
check if a ui input has been registered on this frame
held down timer
auto scroll timer

actions.text: reset both timers to 0 when no inputs are being pressed
